example.code: PS C:\>$Tag = New-Object Amazon.EC2.Model.Tag PS C:\>$Tag.Key = "Test" PS C:\>Remove-EC2Tag -Resource "i-1a2b3c4d" -Tag $Tag -Force
example.description: This example shows how to delete a specific tag for an instance regardless of the tag value. Specifying the -Force parameter means that you will not be prompted to confirm the deletion. This example is compatible with PowerShell v2 or higher.
This example shows how to remove a tag value from an instance for PowerShell v3 or higher.

example.code: PS C:\>$Tag = New-Object Amazon.EC2.Model.Tag PS C:\>$Tag.Key = "Test" PS C:\>$Tag.Value = "Tag value to match" PS C:\>Remove-EC2Tag -Resource "i-1a2b3c4d" -Tag $Tag -Force
example.description: This example shows how to delete a specific tag for an instance only if the tag value matches. Specifying the -Force parameter means that you will not be prompted to confirm the deletion. This example is compatible with PowerShell v2 or higher.

example.code: Remove-EC2Tag -Resource "i-1a2b3c4d" -Tag @{ Key="Test"; Value="Tag value to match" } -Force
example.description: This example shows how to remove a tag value from an instance only if the tag value matches, for PowerShell v3 or higher.

This example, for PowerShell v3 or higher, shows how to remove multiple tags from an instance. PowerShell v2 users should use the New-Object cmdlet to instantiate the Tag objects to be passed to the -Tags parameter.

This example, for PowerShell v3 or higher, shows how to remove multiple tags from multiple instances. PowerShell v2 users should use the New-Object cmdlet to instantiate the Tag objects to be passed to the -Tags parameter.
